content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-267-34-A |Item_parent=Disorders of acid-base equilibrium and hydro-electrolytic disorders |Item_parent_short=Disorders of acid-base balance and fluid and electrolyte disorders |Rank=A |Title=Know when to prescribe blood calcium levels and define hypocalcaemia. |Description=Threshold, interpretation according to albumin level, ionised calcaemia |Rubric=Definition |Contributors=P Rieu; B Moulin; M Flamant |Order=34}} *Definitions **Total hypocalcaemia is defined as a plasma concentration of less than 2.20 mmol/L, and ionised hypocalcaemia as a concentration of less than 1.15 mmol/L. ** *Calcemia measurement to look for hypocalcemia when : **symptoms suggestive of hypocalcaemia (neuromuscular disorders, cardiac disorders) **pathology at risk of hypocalcaemia (chronic renal failure, history of parathyroid surgery).

question.title: When measuring calcium levels to look for hypocalcemia, what is a key factor to consider?
question.description: A question about the conditions under which calcium levels should be measured

option_a.title: Only in patients with symptoms of hypocalcemia
option_a.description: A plausible but incorrect option that might be tempting

option_b.title: When albumin levels are normal
option_b.description: A distractor that might be confusing due to the relationship between albumin and calcium binding

option_c.title: In patients with chronic renal failure
option_c.description: A correct option that highlights an important condition at risk of hypocalcemia

option_d.title: When total calcium levels are below 2.20 mmol/L
option_d.description: A distractor that specifies a specific threshold, but is not the correct answer

correct_option.title: None of the above
correct_option.description: The correct answer that highlights the need to consider multiple factors
